Symposium topics succumb to scrutiny
By BOB DANNER
The Student Council
Selections Committee is now
conducting interviews to
determine which of the proposed
MSE Symposium topics will go
before the student body in a
referendum scheduled for late
April.
Fifteen topics have been
submitted to the Committee for
consideration. A minimum of
twelve of these must be put to a
vote of the student body.
The Selections Commitee,
along with Sinan Serbes and
Michael DePriest, co-chairmen of
the 1974 Symposium, have
begun screening the proposals
and sponsors.
The topics which receive the
most votes will go back to the
Committee for intensive study. If
one topic captures a majority of
the votes cast, it will be

designated as the selected
program without further
consideration by the Committee,
Last year only seven topics
were registered with the
Selections Committee, of which
no more than four could be put
on the ballot. The selected
program won by a plurality of
the votes. In contrast the system
used in 1972 involved only the
SC Selections Committee. The
present process is actually a
compromise between the two
previous ones.
Andy Fredman, chairman of
the Selections Committee, said,
"In one way the new procedure
appears to involve less student
input. If one topic does not draw
a majority, the final selection
falls to the Committee. Now,
however, the students see more
topics."
The proposed topics presented

to the students will he those that
the committee believes most
feasible. Since specific
information such as the names of
the sponsors, provisions for
finance, and the speakers list will
not be available to the students
the Committee believes it is
justified in keeping the
responsibility for the final
decision.
Fredman pointed out, "It is
inappropriate to release a speaker
list before the people involved
are contacted and recruited. The
names of the students who
submitted programs are being
withheld to prevent a political
selection."
He concluded, "When the
three topics come back to the
Committee we will have at our
disposal all the information that
is pertinenet. It seems to me the
logical and efficient system."

According to the Commitee
Chairman, a wide range of topics
were entered though there is
some overlapping. Some
programs are very specific while
others cover a broad spectrum of
ideas.
"There does not seem to be
any trends or directionality to
the subjects proposed. They all
seem to reflect the large amount
of work that was put into them
since the proposals are well
organized and thought out,"
Fredman commented.
The committee will try to pick
the most entertaining and
informative program wihtout
holding one dimension in
preference to the other. Their
target is a well-rounded program,
Fredman said.
"The chosen topic will have
undergone a very competitive
process," Fredman asserted.

Jays the win.

Symposium topics succumb to scrutiny
By BOB DANNER
The Student Council
Selections Committee is now
conducting interviews to
determine which of the proposed
MSE Symposium topics will go
before the student body in a
referendum scheduled for late
April.
Fifteen topics have been
submitted to the Committee for
consideration. A minimum of
twelve of these must be put to a
vote of the student body.
The Selections Commitee,
along with Sinan Serbes and
Michael DePriest, co-chairmen of
the 1974 Symposium, have
begun screening the proposals
and sponsors.
The topics which receive the
most votes will go back to the
Committee for intensive study. If
one topic captures a majority of
the votes cast, it will be

designated as the selected
program without further
consideration by the Committee,
Last year only seven topics
were registered with the
Selections Committee, of which
no more than four could be put
on the ballot. The selected
program won by a plurality of
the votes. In contrast the system
used in 1972 involved only the
SC Selections Committee. The
present process is actually a
compromise between the two
previous ones.
Andy Fredman, chairman of
the Selections Committee, said,
"In one way the new procedure
appears to involve less student
input. If one topic does not draw
a majority, the final selection
falls to the Committee. Now,
however, the students see more
topics."
The proposed topics presented

to the students will he those that
the committee believes most
feasible. Since specific
information such as the names of
the sponsors, provisions for
finance, and the speakers list will
not be available to the students
the Committee believes it is
justified in keeping the
responsibility for the final
decision.
Fredman pointed out, "It is
inappropriate to release a speaker
list before the people involved
are contacted and recruited. The
names of the students who
submitted programs are being
withheld to prevent a political
selection."
He concluded, "When the
three topics come back to the
Committee we will have at our
disposal all the information that
is pertinenet. It seems to me the
logical and efficient system."

Chairman, a wide range of topics
were entered though there is
some overlapping. Some
programs are very specific while
others cover a broad spectrum of
ideas.
"There does not seem to be
any trends or directionality to
the subjects proposed. They all
seem to reflect the large amount
of work that was put into them
since the proposals are well
organized and thought out,"
Fredman commented.
The committee will try to pick
the most entertaining and
informative program wihtout
holding one dimension in
preference to the other. Their
target is a well-rounded program,
Fredman said.
"The chosen topic will have
undergone a very competitive
process," Fredman asserted.
